Questions.question: What is Git?
What does the term "repo" stand for in Git?
Which command is used to initialize a Git repository in a directory?
What command is used to stage changes for a commit in Git?
Which command is used to view the status of your changes in Git?
What command is used to create a new branch in Git?
Which command is used to merge branches in Git?
What command is used to revert changes to a specific commit in Git?
Which command is used to push changes from a local repository to a remote repository in Git?
What command is used to clone a remote repository to your local machine in Git?
What does the command 'git pull' do in Git?
answers: Pushes changes from a local repository to a remote repository
Fetches changes from a remote repository and merges them into the current branch
Creates a new branch in the local repository
Reverts changes made in the working directory
Questions.correct: Fetches changes from a remote repository and merges them into the current branch

Questions.question: What is the purpose of the '.gitignore' file in a Git repository?
answers: To list files that should never be committed to the repository
To specify which files should always be included in commits
To store the credentials for accessing remote repositories
To define the structure of the repository
Questions.correct: To list files that should never be committed to the repository

Questions.question: What does the 'HEAD' pointer refer to in Git?
answers: The latest commit on the current branch
The index where changes are staged before committing
The main branch of the repository
Questions.correct: The latest commit on the current branch

Questions.question: Which command is used to create and switch to a new branch in Git?
What is a 'merge conflict' in Git?
answers: A situation where multiple branches can be merged without conflict
An error that occurs when attempting to merge branches
A situation where Git cannot determine which changes to accept during a merge
A conflict between team members regarding the use of Git
Questions.correct: A situation where Git cannot determine which changes to accept during a merge

Questions.question: What is the purpose of the command 'git rebase'?
answers: To merge changes from one branch into another branch
To rewrite the commit history of a branch
To revert changes made in a specific commit
Questions.correct: To rewrite the commit history of a branch

Questions.question: What does the command 'git cherry-pick' do?
answers: Creates a new branch from a specific commit
Applies the changes introduced by some existing commits
Undoes the changes made in a specific commit
Deletes a branch from the repository
Questions.correct: Applies the changes introduced by some existing commits

Questions.question: Which Git command is used to show the commit history for a specific branch?
What is the purpose of the 'git stash' command?
answers: To discard changes in the working directory
To temporarily store changes that are not ready to be committed
To create a backup of the entire repository
Questions.correct: To temporarily store changes that are not ready to be committed

Questions.question: Which keyword is used to prevent a class from being inherited in C#?
What is the purpose of the 'using' directive in C#?

answers: Refers to the base class of the current instance
Refers to the top-level class in the inheritance hierarchy
Refers to the derived class of the current instance
Refers to the parent class of the current instance
Questions.correct: Refers to the base class of the current instance

Questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'override' keyword in C#?
answers: To override a base class method in a derived class
To hide a base class method in a derived class
Questions.correct: To override a base class method in a derived class

answers: A block of code that performs a specific task
Questions.correct: A block of code that performs a specific task

Questions.question: Which keyword is used to define a method in C#?
What is the purpose of method parameters in C#?
Which of the following is NOT a valid return type for a C# method?

answers: Defining multiple methods with the same name but different parameters
Calling a method from another method
Creating a method inside another method
Returning multiple values from a method
Questions.correct: Defining multiple methods with the same name but different parameters

Questions.question: What is the fundamental difference between value types and reference types in C#?
answers: Value types store their data directly, while reference types store a reference to their data
Value types are smaller in size than reference types
Value types can only be used with primitive data types, while reference types can store objects
Value types are immutable, while reference types are mutable
Questions.correct: Value types store their data directly, while reference types store a reference to their data

Questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a value type in C#?
What happens when a value type variable is passed as an argument to a method in C#?
answers: A copy of the value is passed to the method
The original variable is passed to the method
A reference to the value is passed to the method
The value is converted to a reference type
Questions.correct: A copy of the value is passed to the method

Questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a reference type in C#?
What is the default value for a reference type variable in C#?
What is the default behavior of assignment for value types in C#?
answers: A copy of the value is made
A reference to the value is passed
Questions.correct: A copy of the value is made

Questions.question: Which type of variable is stored on the stack in C#?
What is the result of comparing two reference type variables for equality in C#?
answers: It compares the references, not the values
It compares the values, not the references
Questions.correct: It compares the references, not the values

Questions.question: What is an exception in C#?
answers: An error that occurs during the execution of a program
A method for handling user input
Questions.correct: An error that occurs during the execution of a program

Questions.question: How are exceptions handled in C#?
What does the 'finally' block in a try-catch statement do in C#?
answers: It is executed regardless of whether an exception is thrown or not
It is only executed if an exception is thrown
It is only executed if no exception is thrown
Questions.correct: It is executed regardless of whether an exception is thrown or not

Questions.question: Which keyword is used to throw an exception manually in C#?
What is the purpose of exception handling in C#?
answers: To gracefully handle errors and prevent program crashes
Questions.correct: To gracefully handle errors and prevent program crashes

Questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about exceptions in C#?
answers: They can be caught and handled
They can only occur at compile-time
They can be ignored without consequences
Questions.correct: They can be caught and handled

Questions.question: What is a stack trace in C#?
answers: A report of the function call hierarchy when an exception occurs
A data structure for storing method parameters
A way to visualize memory allocation
A method for tracking loop iterations
Questions.correct: A report of the function call hierarchy when an exception occurs

Questions.question: What happens if an exception is thrown within a 'finally' block in C#?
answers: The exception will propagate up the call stack
The exception will be caught and handled
Questions.correct: The exception will propagate up the call stack

What is encapsulation in object-oriented programming (OOP)?
answers: The bundling of data and methods that operate on that data into a single unit
The ability to inherit properties and behavior from another class
The process of creating multiple instances of a class
The ability to modify the behavior of a method in a subclass
Questions.correct: The bundling of data and methods that operate on that data into a single unit

Questions.question: What is inheritance in object-oriented programming (OOP)?
answers: The bundling of data and methods that operate on that data into a single unit
The ability to inherit properties and behavior from another class
The process of creating multiple instances of a class
The ability to modify the behavior of a method in a subclass
Questions.correct: The ability to inherit properties and behavior from another class

Questions.question: What is polymorphism in object-oriented programming (OOP)?
answers: The bundling of data and methods that operate on that data into a single unit
The ability to inherit properties and behavior from another class
The process of creating multiple instances of a class
The ability to modify the behavior of a method in a subclass
Questions.correct: The ability to modify the behavior of a method in a subclass

Questions.question: What is a class in object-oriented programming (OOP)?
answers: A method that belongs to a class

Questions.question: What is an object in object-oriented programming (OOP)?
answers: A method that belongs to a class

Questions.question: What is a constructor in object-oriented programming (OOP)?
answers: A method that is automatically called when an object is created
A method that belongs to a class
A method that modifies the behavior of another method
A method that creates multiple instances of a class
Questions.correct: A method that is automatically called when an object is created

Questions.question: What is a method in object-oriented programming (OOP)?
answers: A function that belongs to a class
Questions.correct: A function that belongs to a class

Questions.question: What is a property in object-oriented programming (OOP)?
answers: A characteristic of an object that has a value
A method that belongs to a class
Questions.correct: A characteristic of an object that has a value

Questions.question: What is abstraction in object-oriented programming (OOP)?
answers: The process of hiding implementation details and showing only essential features of an object
The ability to inherit properties and behavior from another class
The process of creating multiple instances of a class
The ability to modify the behavior of a method in a subclass
Questions.correct: The process of hiding implementation details and showing only essential features of an object

Questions.question: Which of the following is not a principle of object-oriented programming (OOP)?
What is the main purpose of encapsulation in object-oriented programming?
answers: To bundle data and methods together into a single unit
To allow for the reuse of code through inheritance
To create multiple instances of a class
To modify the behavior of a method in a subclass
Questions.correct: To bundle data and methods together into a single unit

Questions.question: What does inheritance enable in object-oriented programming?
answers: The creation of new classes based on existing ones
The ability to modify the behavior of a method in a subclass
The process of creating multiple instances of a class
The bundling of data and methods into a single unit
Questions.correct: The creation of new classes based on existing ones

Questions.question: What is the primary advantage of polymorphism in object-oriented programming?
What is the relationship between a class and an object in object-oriented programming?
answers: A class is a blueprint for creating objects
An object is a blueprint for creating classes
A class and an object are interchangeable terms
A class is a property of an object
Questions.correct: A class is a blueprint for creating objects

Questions.question: What is the purpose of a constructor in object-oriented programming?
answers: To initialize an object when it is created
To define properties and methods of a class
To modify the behavior of a method in a subclass
To create multiple instances of a class
Questions.correct: To initialize an object when it is created

Questions.question: Which term describes the ability of a method to be defined in multiple forms?
What is a method signature in object-oriented programming?
answers: The combination of a method's name and its parameter types
The return type of a method
The access modifier of a method
Questions.correct: The combination of a method's name and its parameter types

Questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a property in object-oriented programming?
answers: To provide controlled access to class fields
To define behavior for a class
To create multiple instances of a class
To bundle data and methods into a single unit
Questions.correct: To provide controlled access to class fields

Questions.question: What does the term 'abstraction' refer to in object-oriented programming?
answers: Hiding unnecessary details and showing only essential features of an object
The ability to inherit properties and behavior from another class
The process of creating multiple instances of a class
The ability to modify the behavior of a method in a subclass
Questions.correct: Hiding unnecessary details and showing only essential features of an object
